text: Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh…

Family Member: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Family Member: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse. Doctor: This is much better than Family Member: Yeah Doctor: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so. Family Member: Yeah Doctor: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us. Family Member: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas… Doctor: The treatment is working and things are looking up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here. Doctor: Well thank you. Family Member: Seriously. Family Member: Because you care, that she listens. Doctor: But and I have also have some donor money Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you can eat. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?

Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that?

Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern. Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: We’re spiritual. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Uh, I just picked up a full-time schedule. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him?

Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him? Doctor: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made? Family Member: He drives. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do – Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay? Family Member: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that. Doctor: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that-

Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know. Family Member: I’m going to keep my eye on- Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Because you have the training already. Family Member: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But she said is so vitally important -

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay. Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.

Family Member: Try something else. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Makes sense? Patient: Okay. Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled.

Patient: Oh, okay. Family Member: Okay? Doctor: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute. Doctor: What is he on? The Norco, right? Family Member: The Norco. He has Doctor: Okay. Ten’s or? Family Member: No. He’s on five. What you need to tell her now while she’s writing, do, do they take your pain completely away? The thing that bothers me is at night, he still doesn’t sleep, and you’re still in pain. Doctor: So should I give you the higher dose, or do you thing? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I can manage. Family Member: And if he doesn’t-

Family Member: I’ve noticed that when he gets enough rest- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He seems to tolerate the next day better. Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: Even if he’s uncomfortable, he’s not irritable and tired – Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent.

Patient: No I haven’t. Doctor: Okay. So we’d like to check your blood test and then call you and if the PSA is not down to zero then we would consider having you get some radiation treatments and send you for a consultation with the radiation doctors. Patient: Mmm. Doctor: If the PSA does go down to zero then we can tell you about some additional testing that we can do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we may do um your paperwork here - an appointment for six months, just kind of like a safety appointment. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good.

Family Member 2: It’s uh essential oils. Doctor: Oh! What kind is it? Family Member 2: It’s Young Living, it’s Breathe Again. It’s one of the rollers they make. Family Member 1: She sells essential oil. Doctor: Young Living. One of our coordinators is a big person in that. And I see her sometimes on Facebook. I didn't know smell this good. Patient: Well some of it does. Family Member 1: Just bring out your little mini ones and show her. Doctor: This one’s really good. Family Member 1: She has Family Member 2: I know we're getting recorded but I'm ready for sleep. Family Member 1: C___ or C___ Family Member 2: I’ll give you my card.

I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But most of the things we'll be measuring will be that area by your bladder that was squishing the kidney. So that's a big spot that we really want to keep an eye on. Then of course, bone stuff, but that's an area and you’d want to know that this stuff is shrinking. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Chemo is chemo. So, you know, like we talked about last time, whether it's the pill version or the IV, we always worry about hair loss, you know, tiredness, how it affects your liver numbers, that's measured by blood. We always worry about your white cells, red cells, platelets- Patient: Right, right. Doctor: -you know, all the words that make you you. But that's why you're here getting, you know= Family Member 1: Monitored. Doctor: Yeah, monitored. And if it's the worst thing you've ever done, stop, start over on something else. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: If you feel fine, and you continue, then thumbs up. So it's a work in progress, really, for all of us. But I think if we just keep communicating, we'll do right by you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so my next step, honestly, is to get M____ in here so that we can just get the timing and things right and logistics. Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today.

Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today. Doctor: No, because this isn't that you know, that oral pill is investigational. So you- the first thing we have to do is have you sign the right papers and make sure that whatever we just discussed, yep, get it get the copy at home, just so everybody's on the same page. Family Member 3: When does it start? Doctor: So we're hoping to start within a couple of weeks or but you know, or even sooner, because there’s that time crunch. Family Member 1: It worries me that, it’s aggressive, his cancer. Doctor: It is. It is. Family Member 1: So with him walking around, not on anything that is upsetting me. Doctor: Of course. Family Member 1: And him too. Patient: So I have to continue the Dexamethasone? Doctor: Yes. For now, until we sort of straighten out the timing Patient: Because I’ll be running out what- next Tuesday? Family Member 1: I’ll call.

Family Member 1: I’ll call. Doctor: Yeah. All right. Family Member 1: So did W___ then tell you that he's been getting these cramps in his legs? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, that and then number two, he did say you know, his gums are real sensitive, but he never told me. Patient: Oh no, no, no. That was when I was taking the Elida. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right.

Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.

Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard. Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: It’s pretty strong. Doctor: I like that better and less addictive than Ambien. Family Member 1: Oh, okay. Okay, questions. My one daughter is pregnant. Then we watch her her little two year old. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: About three times a week.

Family Member 1: About three times a week. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: He asolutely loves her. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: And he was letting her eat off of him like if he took a bite of his own now. Doctor: That’s a no. Family Member 1: Yeah. Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?

Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him. Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it?

Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her. Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there. Doctor: So same thing, I would just bring a pair of gloves, your own towels and then you wipe and just get a bag that you throw off the stuff. You know what's hard is toddlers get into everything. And you just can't help it. They're curious. Family Member 1: Well, it wouldn't be just for the toddler. Like we all use the main bathroom. There's the upstairs. She's still in diapers, so she has where she not trained yet. Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. So you you get one of those Clorox thingy that you pull out. Patient: Yeah. I know.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah. Family Member 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think? Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth.

Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes. Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct. Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum.

Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it just might be that we have something that really does look interesting or promising that we can offer you. I don’t want to go into those details today because I don’t know when that time will come or if it will come. But if that time comes, when we’re deciding between a standard therapy, like the two that I mentioned, or a different experimental therapy, I can give you the consent form, and you can think about it, and if you decide to participate that would be through us. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Because I know the discussion we had initially, uh, was the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That was one of the options. And I used the word, chemo bad. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s bad in terms, you know, the side effects are worse than everything you’ve had so far. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but it can be effective against the cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I personally tend to use chemotherapy later than most of the people. Uh, and part of the reason for that is because we have a lot of trials which, you know, we believe in, of course, because they’re our studies. And we have best of interest in them. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we have laboratory research on those things, so we are excited, you know –

Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that? Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure. Family Member: Aside from the fact, do we have an appointment time for September fifth? Only because I just need to know so that if I need to adjust my schedule at school, um, so. Healthcare Professional: So, September fifth, nine-thirty lab work, and ten-thirty, the visit. So the time is nine-thirty to ten-thirty. Family Member: Now, for the next, I guess, will be continue to have doctor at ten-thirty? Doctor: Not necessarily. If you wants them at K___, who’s there that day, what the schedule looks like. Do you prefer later or earlier? Family Member: Mm, I mean. Doctor: Yeah. L___ can help with scheduling. If you prefer, like an afternoon appointment, let’s say, instead of morning, or if you want to be like the very first patient that comes in. The lab I think opens at six a.m. So we have some patients that come like at six and then see that doctor. Most people don’t want to come that early.

Patient: And, and I want you to know that I, I thought this discussion was going to be today. Doctor: I’m glad I met your expectations. Patient: Yeah. I thought this was going to come up, and I said, okay. But it is what it is. Healthcare Professional: I will communicate with L___, and she’ll contact you probably tomorrow, about she will get in contact with K. She will set everything up for you. Patient: Okay. Thank you. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead. Doctor: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other. Patient: Yes sir. Yes sir. Now, do I need to go to K___ to get a prescription? Doctor: You’ll wait to hear from us. L___ will help us to do that. L___ will help us to get the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Because normally I think the last two times we were able to, I just told them I would pay for them out of pocket here, but that’s okay. Doctor: I wouldn’t recommend that. Patient: Oh kay. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to give you my card with my number, in case you don’t hear from L___ tomorrow. MD Exits

Family Member: I know. I tolerate this guy all by myself. Doctor: I know. All by yourself. Patient: Come on in and have a seat there. I’ve got friends waiting. Doctor: How come I’m over here? Patient: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter) Patient: No. Doctor: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Is that on purpose for filming? Family Member: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink. Family Member: Oh.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum.

Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Because you know it was nasty when we started. Family Member: I know.

Patient: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch. Doctor: That’s nice. Where you guys going? Patient: Downtown somewhere. Doctor: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there? Family Member: No. Doctor: It’s really good. Family Member: Oh. Sounds interesting. Doctor: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: You like it?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street. Family Member: Oh. Patient: You know me better than that. Family Member: Seeing the head doctor. Patient: I’m kind of hanging outside of these. Doctor: Nice. It was good to see you. I’ve got to put up with this all by myself. Family Member: I know. I mean I got a little sick this year, too, so. Didn’t we tell you?

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: She looks great. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: From our first days of meeting. Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right? Doctor: You just being bent over and not looking at anything but the floor. Family Member: Right. Doctor: This is great. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And you’re making music again? Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Creep up. Um hum. Doctor: We rechecked him. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then he’s got a couple of new spots in the bone which just happens to be in your skull. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Which is, you know, no different than it is in the leg and what not but it’s a signal to us. Family Member: Oh. Exactly. Doctor: That something’s breaking through as in the shot itself is not enough. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So then you say, well, shoot, what, what could be my other options? Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then you say words like, chemotherapy. You say words like pills and other treatments. And they’re around.

Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: You give the flu shot. You hope to try to prevent it from getting worse. Family Member: Worse. Um hum. Doctor: So the vaccine therapy wakes up your body’s immune system to try to fight the cancer by itself. Family Member: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: We also have information that at least in the, you know, African American men- Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks.

Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step. Family Member: Right. Patient: So- Doctor: Yeah? Patient: That transfusion you’re talking about, you know, I read up on that way before I came to this hospital. Doctor: Um hum. Okay. Patient: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t think there’s a conspiracy. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: If that’s where you’re going. Family Member: Right. Yeah. Doctor: This is not a trial. It’s an FDA-approved study. Where there is a trial- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar. Family Member: Right. Doctor: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay. Doctor: So that’s where we’re at. Family Member: That’s the proper response. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And, uh, I’m still ready to ask. Doctor: Yep? Family Member: Oh. I ran into a lady.

Family Member: Cells. Oh, okay. Doctor: The other immune therapies are more generic. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: So you don’t need specialty whatever. It just knows to try to go to the areas that is deemed cancer. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s the ones you see on TV now- Doctor: No. This is the only one. Right. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And prostate’s the only one that this is true. Family Member: It’s the only one? Doctor: Now, we are going to move on to those kinds of treatments, but, so far, those ones have not been as successful as it is in other treatments, in other diseases. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Okay. Doctor: That’s where we’re at.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So you know all of this is, one, you have to be okeydokey with the plan. Two, there’s no emergency, but I always like to stay ahead of your cancer. Family Member: Ahead of the game. Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why we’re having this discussion. Hum, and, three, you know, you don’t like this, then we move onto pills. You know? And there I have different trials, different options, and things like that. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just that I always like to try to get this one in. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because we have the opportunity. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So here we are. (pause3sec) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Do you want the paperwork to read?

Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah- Doctor: Huh? Patient: Can you get somebody to send me like five thousand dollars? Doctor: To what? Doctor: Hum, but, then, you guys tell us, but we should make a decision one way or the other. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m going to give you those side effect sheets. Family Member: Yes. Please. Doctor: We’ll start there. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Can I absolutely guarantee that the back isn’t causing the hip? No,- Patient: No. Doctor: -but you don’t technically have back pain right there in that spot that we pointed out. Patient: That is correct. Doctor: So that’s good news. Okay. Patient: But I do have back pain but it’s coming from the Provenge because they told me – Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: -and I read up on the side effects that I would have back pain. Doctor: Right. Patient: But it’s not every night. Doctor: Right. Patient: You follow what I’m saying?

Patient: The thing, yes. Doctor: However, what we need to do is get ahead of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we’ve got the Provenge in. I think there’s another set of pills, these are FDA approved. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It is not experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you know I’m always happy to consider stuff experimental- Patient: Right. Doctor: -but at this moment we don’t have one that is exactly like this. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right. And this is ready to go FDA, four pills a day, Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired?

Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right. Doctor: but I don’t want to be on the back end because you you know in the story that you didn’t share Patient: Yeah. Doctor: with all the stuff related to what you’ve been doing with Dr. P____. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s a whole ‘nother situation as you know Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that is not immediately making us have to worry from a treatment standpoint. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of you, if I want to get better control of this situation – Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: - it’s better that we start thinking about doing this medicine. Patient: Mm, hmm. So what else, what is the other um other than the weakness, the tiredness? Doctor: The other one is we monitor your liver numbers and we do that by blood tests. You know I always check your blood when you come in. Patient: Man… Doctor: We check out your liver and make sure it’s tolerating it. Patient: They’re taking ten or twelve tubes doc every time I get there but I got a good vampire. Doctor: You do, you do have a good vampire. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um and then but so it’s nothing more than the usual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we have a point six percent of a seizure. So less than one percent of folks who normally have heavy alcohol intake. Patient: I don’t drink. Doctor: Right, so we give the stuff a lot in this clinic. Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep and then there’s a starter – a patient starter kit. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: And then we have to get uh, no you’re good (door closes) Patient: Okay, well God is gonna make sure, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: God is gonna make sure the insurance is taken care of – Doctor: Mm, hmm. PAT - because your wasn’t for sure about the Provenge being taken care of… Patient: …and that was like what a hundred grand. Doctor: That was a hundred grand, yeah. Patient: And so and so the insurance took it right off. Doctor: Yep. Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody.

Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody. Doctor: We’re gonna make you the six million dollar man. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, and so yeah, and so and so this is gonna pass too. Doctor: Yes. We again, we’re just being really on top of it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work. Doctor: Yes we did. Patient: Okay. Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when when when can we start taking the pill? Doctor: So what happens is I go through the insurance. They go through a third party vendor. So Diplomate, CVS Caremark, whatever one your insurance you know sends me to. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle.

Patient: Ooooh I wanted to go to the F___. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re having, my church is having a bike blessing on the twenty fourth. Doctor: Of? Patient: Of this month. Doctor: Oh, okay, fine. Patient: And so I wanted to leave… Doctor: Well if you go do that, - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: if you go do that, When do you come back? Patient: I don’t know doc. It might feel good to me. Doctor: That’s nice but you got to come back. So when are you coming back?

Doctor: That’s nice but you got to come back. So when are you coming back? Doctor: Okay. I mean it’s fine if you want to stay there. PAT Yeah. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It’s not like the medicine is gonna be delivered tomorrow. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: By the time I work out all this paperwork, it’s a while. Patient: Okay, alright. That’s cool. Doctor: So you duke it out with your wife – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - in terms of whether you go or not, that’s on you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just know, I have to have you be careful. Patient: I know.

Patient: - you understand is riding that motorcycle. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: You’re just gonna have to be careful. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know it’s a joy for you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just can’t overdo it or you’re gonna be in the hospital between here and F___. You just got to be careful. Even if you end up in the hospital you just call me and I’ll work with your docs. It will be fine. Okay. So just get rest on the road. Patient: Oh yeah, oh yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I mean you know I ain’t stupid. Doctor: Hi. Healthcare Professional: Hi.

Patient: Get it done. Come on C__, come on over here. Doctor: She’s out of here. Patient: You know what man. Doctor: Here’s your starter kit. Patient: What is this?. Doctor: There’s some information for you about what this medicine is. And this medicine so see… no wait (pages turning) Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: There’s only one, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue, okay. Doctor: Then less common there’s a whole bunch of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: Back pain, diarrhea, flashes, edema. So it’s everything that you had last…

Patient: Doc, Doc, Doc, that’s another thing. Doctor: What? Patient: I ain’t going to the bathroom regularly and started taking my stool softeners and then I’m mixing up the what-ya-call-it too. Doctor: Yep, that’s what you gotta do. You want me to put this here? I just gave him the side effect sheet. Patient: I need. Family Member: I was gonna look them up anyway. Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: you know it’s not in his head, it’s here and that’s the only part that could go wrong. Family Member: So doctor he hears that it’s okay for him to be on that motorcycle? Doctor: What I’m saying is, for me, I don’t advise it. But if you say medically if there is some reason you can’t be on it, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he asks me is there a medical reason why I can’t be on it? No. Do I think it’s a good idea? Not really. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick.

Patient: Yeah. I’m gonna have a great time on my bike. Doctor: Okay. Just be careful. People worry. That’s all. Patient: I know, I know. I know how to you know make her shut it down. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Call me if you run into trouble. If there’s issues with your insurance we will let you know. Patient: Well doc we ain’t claiming that. Remember you said that last time and we made it. Doctor: I know. Patient: Alright. Love you doc. Doctor: Love you too. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Be well. Patient: Yep.

Healthcare Professional: Yes! Doctor: Yep! Healthcare Professional: Do your thing. Family Member: Hey. How are you? Doctor: I hear I’m missing the show in here. Patient: Your hands are cold, doc. Doctor: I just washed ‘em. How are you? Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Can you repeat – uh, why -- are you saying that he could go on the next trial? Doctor: You could try a trial and see how you do – Patient: Right. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole –

Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It would come out as poop or what? Doctor: Yep. Patient: And I would know, I would know it? Doctor: Oh, yeah. It would smell like poop! Patient: Oh.

Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me -- Doctor: And that’s the key. Patient: Let me ask you this. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. I have an ache in my hands. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: Um. When I try to – if I try to go to the bathroom without takin’ a laxative –

Patient: Right. Doctor: So you have to have loose bowels. That means – Patient: That’s what I’m talkin’ about. Doctor: Soft. Stool softeners. Patient: Stool softeners. Doctor: Absolutely. Patient: They ain’t workin’ like they’re supposed to, doc! Doctor: There’s no way that we can get you not pooping correctly because there’s so many different types of laxatives out there – Patient: Yeah, well. Doctor: You just need to take more. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. You just don’t have enough – Patient: Enough.

Patient: So, now I got gloves that are closed here. Doctor: Okay! Patient: You know what I’m sayin’? I bought long-sleeved shirts. You know what I’m sayin’? You dig? Doctor: So you’re prepared? Patient: I’m prepared. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I -- I’m preparing for that. Doctor: He’s prepared. It’s what he loves to do. Patient: Yeah. I’m – Doctor: But I think her point is you just do it within reason. If you ride twelve hours a day, you’re not drinkin’ fluids, you’re not takin’ your stool softeners, you don’t want to mess yourself up – Patient: I’m --- just listen. Listen to this, doc. Doctor: That’s hard. That’s all.

Patient: I – yeah. Whatever. Doctor: I got a great idea! Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s do this! Family Member: I gotta get out. Doctor: Right. (Laughs) Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day.

Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s sorta breaking through, right? You’re cancer’s already sort of figured out how it works. Patient: Right. Doctor: You’re options are A different standard of care pill, but we worry that if you go from that pill to the other pill, we don’t get a lot of mileage out of that because it’s too similar. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So then we could talk about chemo. (Pause) Patient: Okay. You heard about this cancer pen? Doctor: - no one’s gotten a rash and all that. Patient: - you heard about this cancer pen that they came up with? Doctor: You know how many cancer pills that are out? Patient: No, a pen! Pen! Doctor: Pen?

Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or – Patient: Well, doc, you know -- Doctor: Incontinence or whatever. Patient: Okay. So, no, no. Here, here’s the deal. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Here’s the deal. Okay? (Pause5sec) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: You follow what I’m sayin’, you know? And I know, you know, time might not be that long. You follow what I’m sayin’? You know?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.

Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember? Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream –

Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way. Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday?

Patient: Stomach acid. Doctor: Yeah. Healthcare Professional 2: I can check. Doctor: Who put you on both? Patient: Huh? Doctor: Who put you on both pills? Patient: That came from P_. Doctor: Oh. I don’t know if you need both. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s kind of overkill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll find out what you can take. So, let’s do that. Patient: Hand me my phone, please.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -

Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel – Doctor: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time. Family Member: Poison (chuckles) Doctor: Okay? Patient: And the V___ Patient: I was seeing a doctor V___ in O____ in D____. Doctor: That’s him.

Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t. Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo.

Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Once you (makes sound) Family Member: So, so. Is this going to make him sleepless, like you said a little more energy? Doctor: No, no, it’s only going to help with pain and I think when you get off the Xtandi you’ll actually have more energy because no matter what that Xtandi is making you tired. Patient: Well my energy level isn’t bad. Doctor: Yeah, to you, but we’ve got this one over here going “Heh?” (Chuckles) Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active.
