Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. Now I wish I had a clinical study to offer you at this point, but our Xofigo plus something requires your disease to actually be worse than it is (not that I’m wishing you were on that) Patient: Right.

Family Member: To the next person who needs it. Doctor: And we have a process to do that. Family Member: Somebody that needs it because I know how expensive it is. Doctor: Yes, and we appreciate that. Family Member: Yeah, we’ll bring it back. Doctor: Okay, sounds like a plan. Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Organs are good. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Okay, okay still got diabetes to worry about, not the cancer. Patient: So bone as in spine or is it now in Doctor: Yeah, spine as in spine and pelvis. So it’s right here. Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling. Doctor: That’s – I was going to do a drive-by and get his stinking ladder. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Let her shoot you up, my friend. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m going to get this rolling with Dr. ___. Patient: So it seems to me though that -

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: You had to scare me like that. I have no idea. Family Member: I just gave him some M and M’s. Good thing I brought them in. Not M and M’s but Good and Plenty. Doctor: Why you running so low? Family Member: He ate breakfast but he didn’t eat it all at the restaurant. Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: He had an omelet and toast and .

Family Member: Actually that bread probably isn’t either. But then it tells you not to eat the whole grain stuff Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -after the radiation so we went to- Doctor: Well now you’re hopefully out of the hole. You know? You’re done with radiation. And I hope your back feels better. I hope. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Yeah. It’s a lot better. Doctor: Alright. Did you start on that XTANDI four pills? Did you start your extra pill recently? Family Member: He ran out, they didn’t send enough. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: So he took out that- Patient: Yeah. I explained to the doctor that- Doctor: Um hum.

Patient: I’ve gotta box this up. You know? As it was I was a little bit late Family Member: You ate half of it. Doctor: No. That’s okay. You should never rush to come here. You know that. You just come when you can safely. I’m not going anywhere. So next time just finish whatever you’ve gotta finish. Patient: Well, we, we, we, started now much late. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame. Doctor: I heard there was something going on seventy-five today too. Patient: Middle of that, yes. Doctor: There was some massive drama on seventy-five. Family Member: Oh. Hope we missed it. Patient: No. We ran into it. Doctor: But it was south of here. Something happened south.

Patient: Yeah. We ran into it. Doctor: I don’t know what happened. Somebody tried, I don’t know if it was a suicide case or something but they blocked all the lanes or something was going on. Family Member: Yeah. I heard about that earlier today. Doctor: Something was going on so everybody was all discombobulated today. Family Member: It was north and south going into Ohio. Doctor: Yeah. That’s what it was. That was what it was. A little scary. Family Member: Yeah. I saw that this morning. Doctor: Oh, my. Family Member: North and south was shut down. Doctor: Oh, boy. Patient: No south of us Doctor: Yeah. It was police incident. I’m not sure exactly what they say it was but-

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing. Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Oh, they’re taping us now? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh, I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. We’re getting his whole lunch live right now in color Doctor: Well I’m glad you’re feeling a little better. Just you know take your time. We’re okay. We’ll see what that PSA shows. I’m glad we straightened out the whole pill action and everything else. Patient: Yeah. That’s all been handled. Doctor: But you know with the XTANDI it makes you tired. Then sometimes you don’t really want to eat. And it’s hard, you’re such a tough diabetic to begin with, minus the pills. You being on it like you are is probably the best thing for you to stay on it because you might bottom out a lot faster than normal. Okay? Patient: Okay. Family Member: And he has been going low a little bit now and then. Doctor: Yeah. Well because you’re so used to being very high. Patient: Well, you know, I-no I’m not used to being very high. Doctor: Well, yeah, except when you come here you’re high.

Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

Patient: Well then you mentioned other supplements. Doctor: Right. I think your standard basic multivitamin, it’s a thumbs up. Because that’s just sort of your regular, you know, recommended daily allowance, your recommended daily intake, that’s no problem. But if you start taking high doses of things, we just don’t know what it’s going to do. Family Member: What is that black pill you’re taking? Patient: That’s the macular- Family Member: For macular degeneration? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: It’s a it’s for it’s for your eyes? Patient: Yes. Taking daily for the eyes. Family Member: I don’t know if it’s good to take that either. Is it? Would it be? Doctor: I don’t know. I don’t know what the black pill is. Family Member: Well, it’s a capsule, it’s a capsule and it’s got that- Patient: Gel cap.

Family Member: It’s got the stuff that good for your eyes in it. Doctor: Vitamin E? Family Member: Yeah. Something like that. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know what it’s got in it. Family Member: Alright. Next time. Doctor: Next time so we can look at it. Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC.

Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years. Doctor: Bye guys. I’m happy you can get Family Member: Bye.

Patient: Well, they’re giving me a combination. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: Anything is possible. (Laughter) Patient: It got better. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: Nice to see you. Nice to see you. Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again.

Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No. Doctor: Man, it’s always your darn back. Family Member: Well, hip and leg. Doctor: Is it the hip and leg? Patient: Well, it’s, it like radiates from here down. Family Member: The pelvis down. Doctor: Uh, refresh my memory. Have we ever MRI’d that?

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Like a while ago or recent? Patient: Probably a year ago, I’m guessing. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh, full body, full body MRI? Doctor: No. That site. Because you had the back issue. You do have a nice amount of arthritis as I recall and disk issues there. But, does that seem like it’s the same pain or is it a different pain? Patient: No. It seems to mirror what I was experiencing before. Doctor: Because I think between now and the six weeks that stuffs coming out of you, you decide whether, you know, if it’s looking like even week three of our six-week little holiday here, you go, yeah, you know what, this stuff’s really not getting any better. You call us. We’ll just order the MRI. Poof. Done. Family Member: He’s supposed to see Dr. V___ in a couple of weeks. Doctor: Good. Good. Patient: I think it’s July second - Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: He had a muffin. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: On the way here. So I ate that, came in, and got my blood drawn. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So, yeah, that’ll kick it up quite a bit from what, you know? You’re not, you’re not happy with anything I’m telling you. (Laughter) Doctor: No. Three eighty five is just bad. Patient: I understand. Yes, it is. It is. It is. Family Member: He had egg McMuffins today, too. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I had an egg McMuffin, but you know what? I ate it without a muffin. (Laughter) Doctor: I was going to say, maybe you do it without the muffin. I think the hemoglobin A one C is one reflection but it’s not the only reflection, and- Patient: I thought that was the more accurate of the two. Doctor: Yes and no, but you shouldn’t - you should have some stability in your sugar. You know what I mean?

Patient: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Doctor: Three eighty five, no matter where you are in your day, is too high. Patient: Yes. Yeah. Family Member: It will make you feel sick. Doctor: It’ll make you feel sick. Family Member: And tired. Doctor: Yeah. Especially now, I’m not even doing a thing to poison you, you should feel better. Doctor: Um hum. So is that the highest? Patient: So absolutely. Absolutely. I don’t, I don’t get readings like that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? It can be in the two twenties. You know? Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: And then you eat breakfast. Patient: And then I’ll get up again and check it again. Doctor: Alright. Yeah. I think you could get off the carbs. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It would be better. That’s all. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta.

Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it. Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it.

Family Member: I brought juice. Doctor: Remember that? Doctor: I saw him last time. It was a whole lot of fun. A whole lot of fun. Doctor: How have the sugars been at home? Patient: They’ve been doing good. Doctor: Yeah? Good, good or mah good? Patient: Mah good. Doctor: Okay. Why is that? Because you’re (clears voice) Patient: Um, maybe a little of both. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But I, I, you know, I’m religious in checking my sugars. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. And when do we expect to leave your dad’s house? Patient: I think we’re supposed to be getting the keys to the house we’re purchasing next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But that doesn’t mean we’re moving in next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re probably going to have some work done. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And stay at dad’s until it’s all done. Doctor: So it might be a couple of months.

Patient: What’s the number? Doctor: Excellent. Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that again? I’m sorry. Family Member: Hum? Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that? Family Member: Yes. (Patient gives phone number.) Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks?

Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: -you’re coming back. Call me a little hyper-anal. Doctor: Yes. Let’s do that. Doctor: I am. Good plan. Right? Plus it’ll keep you more on track if you know that you have to come in and we check your sugars and yeppers. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of-

Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: So nobody goes in? Patient: Not unless they have to pick up something. They can't stay because there's not air conditioning. The HVAC is turned off. Doctor: Holy mackerel that’s like serious. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you think you guys will ever go back someday? Hard to say? Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm.

Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay.

Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay. So I think, you know, depending on so you'll finish reading the consent, if it's of interest call M___ back and say, okay, their next step would be to bring you in and actually formally review everything and get blood work on that day- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now.

Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All right. Doctor: Well, good. It was nice to see you. I'm glad we had a chance to chat and you know, if it's good then call M___ and I’ll tell her to be on the lookout. Patient: Okay. So it's up to me to call her and let her know. Doctor: Well I’ll have her call you too. But that way, you know that at your convenience if you're at work, and she calls you that you can call her back. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Good. You remember my daughter, E_______? Doctor: Yes, of course! Family Member: Hi. Doctor: She was your-- Family Member: Nice to see you! Doctor: Lucky charm. Patient: You're right. Doctor: Okay, we have a medical student. I think they told you that he will be in. Did she tell you that? Patient: Yeah. That's right, yeah. That's right. Doctor: Um, okay, that um... Patient: That's fine. Patient: Good. The drops have been helping. Doctor: The redness is all gone. How about the tearing? Even that is better?

Patient: Yeah, that's better. The pain-- Doctor: Okay. Patient: is, the drops help on that. There's no pain, the throb it’s not there. Doctor: Alright, then now let me see though (whispering) Patient: You were just covering it a little bit there. (pause) Doctor: This one is weeping? Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo? Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due? Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or--

Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so. Doctor: You could probably talk the medical lingo pretty easily now. Patient: Yeah, right. (Slight laughter) Healthcare Professional: Yes. Patient: I saw a news lady on TV --- Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: -- And I thought of, I thought of T____.

Patient: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And then I went to see a doctor, L__, a radiologist, - Doctor: Mm hm. Mm hm. Patient: -and he’s going to radiate lymph nodes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Now I get the impression he might do more than just the two that were were pressing right now. Doctor: I think that would be important for us because Patient: Yeah. Doctor: we may need to you know not treat them all and leave one so that you’re actually eligible- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -for the trial, which is a terrible thing to say.

Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name)

Patient: So and - Doctor: Okay. We’ll get a plan. Patient: So it was described to be by the nurses. It’s the last time they tweak the aim if they’re not exactly satisfied with the - Doctor: Mm hmm, it might be IMRT, you know sort of image modulated radiation therapy. Patient: Don’t know that. Doctor: Okay, so I can check with him. I know what M___s going to do is try to have you sign a form so we could see if you could be eligible for this other study. Um, it is a pill drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, a biologic, so not a chemo. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many, many arms of this trial. It’s like the octopus study. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where there’s a lot. But you’re basically taking a pill. There is a pathway that’s always screwed up with prostate cancer. This sort of tackles that pathway.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness. Patient: Hmm, I’m an expert on that. Patient: Yeah, fortunately you know - Doctor: Mm hmm and you weren’t too bad. Patient: You know being a retiree, Doctor: Yeah, Patient: I mean I can sleep.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it. Patient: He’s a terrific doctor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m really fortunate to have him as a doctor. Doctor: Yes, I agree. Patient: And I enjoy him as a personality- Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: And I have I mean it’s a fact. But that one time was bad so then I just had it um (pause) Doctor: Okay. Yeah Patient: Two weeks ago today and it wasn’t nearly as bad. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But it’s also not seeming to work like it did. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. I hear the PSA is starting to creep up a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan

Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. VIP apparently you are. Patient: Well, probably. Doctor: Well we said we just really need to know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know so we’re we’re doing the whole we gotta come up with the next study uhh situa - and the good part is there’s more trials that opened up. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling. Doctor: Yeah. She’s pretty good. Patient: In fact I think um Doctor: Okay Patient: Dr. S____ put me on um oh what is it? It’s a, it must be a diuretic, but it’s I can tell you… Doctor: Mmm. Oh hydrochlorothiazide or Lasix? Patient: It’s not a Lasix or at least I don’t know (sound of zipper)

Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah so if you call and say hey who’s out there with uh you know at the R___ Branch, um… Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s - there’s many, there’s many, but they literally are all good. Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ … Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: …and operates out of the uh works out of the uh W____ location. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Makes it easier for us. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know your numbers always suggest that you’re dry. You know like you’re just a tad dehydrated. It always runs a little high. The other number we check is the B.U.N. or the bun.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: When you put those two together like a ratio, you’re a little dry so you need fluids. Patient: I, unfortunately, the last two days that’s been a little bit difficult because I was sitting in meetings. Doctor: Ahh. Okay. Patient: And driving so uh. Doctor: So you don’t really take fluids when you’re sitting in meetings… Patient: Well I don’t take as many… Doctor: …and driving. Patient: I don’t take as many fluids… Family Member: Not as much. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: If he thinks of it he can get it anywhere he is. Patient: Because I drink water. I like water. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: You’re gonna have to make it an effort then get in to see the nephrology folks… Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: … ‘cause you’re at that you know anywhere from like one-six to one-nine and it’s not that big of a jump. Patient: Right. Doctor: But then if you get over two and things like that life gets harder. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’re straining that one kidney bean too much. Patient: Right.

Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: That it’s gone “kablooee.” Yeah. Patient: The only thing that was concerning me Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Was that occasionally I have some hip pain, but I don’t. Ya know.. Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: You know, I’m not sure that that’s not.. uh, oh

Family Member: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Doctor: That was Xtandi. So, tiredness. One of them has a low platelet issue. Like, you take it, and your platelets are gone. You stop it; the platelets come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that, Patient: No. Doctor: but it’s just, you know, we obsess about numbers. So, we’re like, “GAHHHH, where’d the platelets go?” And, that’s that. Appetite loss… Family Member: Ohhhh… (laughter) Doctor: Can occur which we can only pray for. Doctor: I would say that’s about it. I mean, in terms of what I really see people feeling bad about. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the fatigue, you know, for somebody like you who is on the go constantly could be significant. Like, I don’t want to minimize that in the . You have

Family Member: Oh, yeah, that’d be great. Patient: So, that’ll be two then. We’ll have two going on at the same time. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you’ll keep your Xtandi, Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm.

Patient: So that’s where, that’s where I thought… Family Member: That’s what we just assumed it was… Doctor: Exactly. So now we’re just being super careful that you’re aware and you’re not bungee jumping and landing on your left hip and making that hurt worse. Doctor: Yeah I know. You’re not exactly outright denying me right now the bungee jumping that you’re starting to scare me or zip lining. Doctor: Terrific. Patient: I’m just thinking, I want to ask you now, Doctor: Nothing Patient: I, I’m pleased with where we’re at. Family Member: So. Doctor: I’m gonna order the x-ray. I’m gonna send you guys over there because they’re all screaming at me. They’re gonna… Patient: Order the x-ray for? Doctor: Hip.

Patient: Yeah. Well I know that’s true. Doctor: But that’s a whole ‘nother story. But that way if you do call me one day out of the blue, I’m gonna be like yeah we just checked your hip thing remember and it was a couple months ago and you were fine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Blood work… Doctor: Might as well get it done. Patient: Blood work everything – can I do that with the Zometa too or when we do the Zometa Doctor: Yeah. Patient: can we do the x-ray the same day? Doctor: Sure. Easy. Patient: Or were you thinking of – you were thinking of doing… Doctor: It doesn’t matter. Whatever. There’s no emergency guys. Whenever is convenient for you. Patient: I see. Okay. Okay. Doctor: So you decide when you want to do it.

Patient: Oh my God! Doctor: It’s down. You’re down to three point seven. Patient: And that was when? Doctor: Today. Patient: No kidding? Doctor: No kidding. One dose of chemo. Patient: mumbling (sound of door) Doctor: Here I’ll take that. Remember to take it okay with you. Oh! Careful. Don’t lean on that chair. Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay. So as in one day you get the chemo, the second day you come in and just get that shot. Patient: Okay. I think that’s what B do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: it as soon as possible. Okay but the chances of that happening are very small. The biggest thing is the second chemotherapy doesn’t have any danger to the nerves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like this one. I don’t like… Doctor: No. Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling.

Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications…

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Your blood pressure and stuff, we’ll send those in. Patient: Okay. Because I said my vitamins, that’s what, that boosts me up. Because like when I’m fatigued I can’t get up, I take one of those vitamins. Doctor: That helps. Patient: And I’m off and running. Yes sir. I’m off running man. Doctor: Now are you still taking prednisone? Patient: That’s what I’m like, that’s what I was trying to tell you. That’s the way he didn’t know what I take. He said you still taking the prednisone Doctor: So you need a new script? Patient: Yeah I need a new script, all of that. Doctor: Because even with this new chemo I need to continue the prednisone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m telling you.

Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yet? Patient: I just got it just now. Doctor: You did get it okay good. Patient: A couple days ago. Doctor: Yeah because the flu has been bad this year so. Healthcare Professional 1: So he’ll be due for the Lupron his next visit correct? Doctor: Yep Healthcare Professional 1: Okay. Doctor: Well I mean you might as well get it authorized. Healthcare Professional 1: Right. Doctor: If he’s one day here or there (mumbling)

Healthcare Professional 1: So did you make another appointment to see Dr. G____? Patient: Yeah uh uhhh… Doctor: Okay so they gave you enough? Patient: I think she said March – March, March something, March twenty-third or something. Doctor: Okay, alright. Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.

DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay?

Patient: So, I say, yeah, I tell her can she get a script so I can call my insurance and see where I can get a cheap one at. Doctor: Yeah. I don’t think I will be able to justify a scooter for you. Okay? Based on just this disease. Believe me, I have given that script to other people, and it has not worked for people who are sick or older than you. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, I don’t think it will work. Okay? Uh, beyond that, if you want to see a neurologist, get tested, and see if they would be willing to give you, that’s perfectly okay with me. Patient: Uh, what, a what? Doctor: Neurologist. A nerve specialist. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now,

Patient: I’ve been lost that. I’ve been lost that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But I lost more. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Look what I got up in here. All this is brand new. Everything is brand new. I got, uh, Doctor: At least you have an ID now, huh? Patient: Yeah, I got an ID. Patient: I doubt anybody gonna give me a Social Security card, though. Doctor: Let’s see on here. Um. So, you have Lupron and Patient: I was, I was lookin’ forward to takin’ that chemo, but I wasn’t worried about it. I just wanted to see whether, see this is what I wanted to do. I wanted to take it, G_ so I could see what type of effect would it take and then I would know and Doctor: No. Not if you just had started diarrhea, like just two, three days ago again. Patient: But I don’t know, I don’t know, I don’t know if it was the chemo ‘cuz I just had it, um Doctor: No. I don’t want the chemo to aggravate anything.

Patient: So, I don’t need this, right? Doctor: No. Show them this paperwork, but show them that, I was gonna say, show them that so that you make sure they cancel and give you a new one. Okay. But anyway, that’s fine. Patient: I’ll, I’ll Doctor: Show them this paperwork, and then they’ll give you all of those appointments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me go work on your scripts, and I’ll be back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I ain’t gotta take no shots, no hip shots, or Doctor: You are due for your Lupron. So, Patient: Which one is that? Doctor: The hormone. The Lupron shot.

Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You have an appointment there anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Yep. Well. Doctor: The ibuprofen as needed? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The lisinopril with the water pill in it, one pill a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: And you’ve got your tapazole, huh, methimazole. Doctor: Morphine. You’ve got, huh, fifteen milligrams as needed? Your multivitamin once a day? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Your potassium two times a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: Prednisone one pill twice a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s what I have. Anything else you’re taking that I don’t know about?

Patient: Well, besides that, huh, that pain I’m still getting. Except for now I’m getting a pain right here. I’m thinking this is from this. I’m not sure. But, huh- Doctor: So where’s the pain at that you had before? Patient: Down in here. Doctor: In your buttock? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or it’s hips and buttock? Patient: Hip. Doctor: Okay. Huh, okay, and, huh, any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And how’s your headaches been? Patient: One side of pain right here, I don’t have any. Doctor: And no trouble swallowing?

Patient: No. I don’t have any. Doctor: Still any numbness around your mouth or-? Patient: A little bit when, you know, coughing. Doctor: So. So how often are you taking the morphine? Patient: About two at night. Doctor: A little, nothing during the day? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily?

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: How’s your hot flashes? Patient: They come out all the time. (Laughs) Doctor: And urine. Any trouble passing your water? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Okay. And they didn’t keep you in the hospital. Anything new since I saw you a couple of weeks ago that you want to tell me about? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Let’s put that there. Okay. Any other bumps or lumps that you’ve noted? Any rashes, skin changes?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Because I don’t want to go too far with the numbness, huh, if that’s a possibility. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One of the things about the positive thing about the vitamin C is there is some bit of the people get less numbness. Huh, normally after three or four doses of the chemotherapy, huh, we have a sense of whether it’s helping. Your PSA may be lower. Your pain may be better. Huh, huh, those are sort of some of the clues. Okay? Huh, if we feel like it’s, you are getting better, we’re going to keep going as far as ten treatments. Huh, if after three or four doses, your pain’s worse, your PSA is higher, huh, I might even get scans after the fourth cycle to follow your lymph nodes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, because if your PSA is going up, and your lymph nodes are getting bigger, we’re not going to keep giving you the chemotherapy if it’s causing all those side effects. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right.

Patient: I think, I think you answered all my questions pretty good. Huh, the only thing, the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: When would that start? Doctor: Huh, so, it, that would start if you are doing the clinical trial, then once you sign the paper, you could start a couple of days after that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so it’s not going to delay getting that started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Huh, we might make the decision when you’re back in a month, huh, and then we can go from there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you need a refill on your morphine? Or are you good? Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you’re set there. And there’s probably nobody out there right now. Patient: Right. Doctor: I always end up with you late in the day. Doctor: At least you don’t have to go to the ER tonight. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? So then I’ll let you head out and, huh, we’ll check on whether the trial makes sense. So I’ll say, read the consents, we will review your records to see if eligible, because if you need blood, I can give you a blood transfusion, but the hep C we may not be able to. Patient: Right. Doctor: This tells you, you know, you can read the consent. We’ll review your records to see if you’re eligible. Otherwise, we can start the chemo in a few weeks. Stop the abiraterone now. Continue on the prednisone. It says stop the abiraterone, and it tells you on this page that I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then it says that, huh, I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Family Member: You look cute. Doctor: Thank you. You know it’s interesting how guys never notice and every one of the spouses has noticed. (Laughs) Patient: Well it’s something, a non-prescription over-the-counter thing doc. Doctor: Oh, okay. Patient: They didn’t have antivert. Family Member: They don’t seem to use it. Doctor: Oh you were in Canada. Family Member: The doctor didn’t even want to – he wouldn’t prescribe it, then he did prescribe it and we went to the pharmacy and they said we don’t carry it. Patient: But he directed us to an over-the-counter thing that worked really well. So that helped a lot. Doctor: It must have been scopolamine or something. Family Member: Yeah it was for anti-nausea. Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening.

Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip? Patient: Previously we were under the impression that the scans were the good news that they haven’t changed. Doctor: I think that is still true. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now.

Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. So honestly for the Lynparza I would really push for getting the Lynparza… Patient: The Lynparza is the uh inhibitor? Doctor: Is the pills. The PARP inhibitor. Yes. For the BRCA mutation. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct. Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter)

Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm. Patient: Yeah Lupron continues regardless of any of the options? Doctor: No matter what that continues and then we add other things on top. Patient: Even with the PARP inhibitor or the chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Lupron goes with the chemo? Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor: Different than the one he’s on. Yes. Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So we use Lupron Family Member: Shots? Doctor: Mhm. So people get hot flashes. People get low libido, can have erectile dysfunction. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend.

Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence. Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month.

The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay.
