Doctor: Do it yourself, but otherwise, if you just tell the operator then at eight hundred to page what - Patient: Give me your Christmas present. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Okay (chuckles) Patient: No, there you go.

Patient: No, there you go. Doctor: Oh, thank you. Patient: You’re welcome. Doctor: That is very sweet. Family Member: Yeah, it is. Doctor: Thank you, that’s special, though; thank you. Okay, so the other big thing is that this chemo will cause hair loss. You probably will notice; most people notice it after about a couple of courses. But you know it’s possible Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks.

Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s -

Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that - Doctor: Yeah, that we could not have continued it. Patient: At least - Doctor: But you really had a off-the-chart benefit with that. Okay. Agreed. Patient: And if I had you know two more treatments, would it have been enough you know? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH!

Patient: I guess I can cross that off my list (chuckles) Doctor: Yeah, I think. Patient: Oh did you get a new car yet? Doctor: I did. UNISON OH! Healthcare Professional: Oh you got a new car? Family Member: Oh no, you’re kidding. Doctor: Well I did because my daughter has taken mine. So I badly needed one. I mean I needed a set of wheels for sure. Family Member: Oh! Doctor: So it wasn’t by choice. Healthcare Professional: What kind of car did you get? Family Member: Did you get your Caddy? Doctor: I did not. No, he wanted me to get a Cadillac. No, no, I got a Mercedes. Family Member: Oh, all right!

Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. Healthcare Professional: He had a Buick Encore; that’s a nice car, too. Family Member: Yeah, that was a beautiful car. Doctor: Yeah, so now he’s. So she was sort of joking that if you get any girls’ phone calls, that’s the reason he’s getting them, not - Family Member: Oh my god! Patient: Yeah, “Mom, can I borrow your car?”

Healthcare Professional: You had one, oh yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, that’s what my daughter has taken. It’s pretty old. It still runs great. Family Member: She can’t walk out the front door and be on the same level as you know. She’d got to go down a little bit before she can come back. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: every kid needs thinking they’re going to change. Doctor: Yeah, no I wouldn’t give them new cars anyway. Patient: That’s normal to buy a new car, yeah. Doctor: Who wants to pay that insurance, too? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so now we will probably move you guys to Wednesday, Tuesday or Wednesday. Which day would you prefer? Family Member: You pick. Patient: Wednesday’s fine.

Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. HCP Okay, so these will be sent. Do we have a - Doctor: In the R___, Yeah. (Pause 10 second) Patient: Oh yeah, they’re like, the pens he has are just like Cadillacs; they’re big. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: They’re big but they’re light-weight, and they have the new type points on them. Doctor: My gosh, you do notice stuff. Wow! Even I didn’t know that.

Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do? Patient: I need my OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah the OxyContin you’re gonna get no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That you keep going. Patient: Okay. Take Percocet… Doctor: Instead of the Norco.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right. Healthcare Professional: Alright. Doctor: So let’s do that, see how you do and then we’ll switch, we’ll add the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because too many changes if the pills don’t match well together. Patient: Well I wouldn’t take them all at one time nowhere, if I take my other pill then I wait another hour and then I take that. Doctor: Okay. Well you definitely cannot take the Ambien and the Restoril together. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Are you going to remember that? Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again?

Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again? Doctor: Restoril. This new sleeping pill. If I give you that… You know what, next time just bring all your Ambien pills and all that. Patient: Okay. I sure will. Doctor: That way, then I will give you the new sleeping pill prescription. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out.

Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So with the Percocet you’re actually going lower on the dose of the OxyContin. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re okay with that? Patient: Okay. What you think? Doctor: Well I don’t think it’s going to be all that much better for you, but if you think so I’m willing to give it a try instead of the Norco. Patient: Okay well I’m with you. Doctor: Keep taking the OxyContin in the morning and in the evening. Patient: Right. That’s what I do. Doctor: Don’t change that. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: Okay and then instead of the Norco you use the Percocet. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that? Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Well I thought maybe you was gonna give me another twenty and ninety. That’s what I was asking. Doctor: Well the Percocet we cannot give more than hundred twenty. Patient: Right. I know, I’m talking about OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah this is a long acting so it’s good for twe- twelve hours. So you only can take it morning and evening. Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight.

Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Patient: Twice, uh, I think they are seventy milligrams twice a day. Doctor: Okay – again, they’re a hundred and fifty or three hundreds? Patient: Oh, okay. Then they must be a hundred and fifties. Doctor: And so you take it once a day or twice a day? Patient: Twice a day. Patient: I try to get a thousand milligrams in. Doctor: Do you take that twice? Patient: Yeah. It depends. Sometimes I’m on gel pills and sometimes I’m on pills, pills. Doctor: So, those are the three medicines you take? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So the Eliquis, the Wellbutrin, and your calcium with vitamin D in it? Patient: Right. Doctor: Nothin’ new? Nothing new for bowels? Anything for pain?

Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on? Doctor: So you’re not – (housework) Patient: Yeah. Chores. (Pause) Doctor: But it gets done the next day or next – or you get it done eventually – or? Patient: Eventually. Laying kitchen floor right now. Doctor: Have you had any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And you take naps? Doctor: Once a day or once – Patient: Once a day. In the afternoon. Four or five o’clock. Doctor: Where do you hurt these days? Patient: No. Doctor: No pain? No discomfort?

Patient: No discomfort. Tired. Doctor: And any chest pain, shortness of breath? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had to go to the hospital for any reason since I last saw ya? Patient: No. Patient: No. Not, not hungry at all. Doctor: What’s your weight been doing? Patient: It’s, uh – two twelve -- Doctor: Two twelve. Patient: Today. Doctor: Is that up or down for you? Patient: It’s probably --

Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes? Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause) Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec)

Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: And this is a – when we look through all the things about what could you do that’s different in here, uh, we have this clinical study – Patient: Oh. Doctor: - and the first thing that we had to check is you had to be ARV seven expressing. Patient: That was so Doctor: So you are ARV seven positive. Patient: Ah. Doctor: That’s a bad thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: That says, um, (laughs) Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh. So you almost have to do something that’s not chemotherapy. Sorry. Something that’s not hormone therapy. Patient: Okay. Is that the –

Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine.

Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So he can let her – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: He can give her the password. The system doesn’t know who’s looking. You know, but it is his password. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay? But you need to be able to call her or talk to her or you have to sign forms out front to give me release. Okay?

Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful)

Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon? Doctor: So what’s gonna happen is we’ll put the prescription in – Family Member: Yep. Doctor: They’ll let us know, and then by e-mail, we’re gonna – or in MyChart – we’re gonna know whether or not you can start it. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then if you start it, then after two weeks – Family Member: Ahhhh.

Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for – Doctor: Yeah, I mean other diseases we’ve had people who, uh, their cancer doesn’t come back. Okay? But we haven’t seen that in prostate cancer. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I mean, I didn’t even have a prostate when I got it. How did that happen? Family Member: I don’t think they always got it all out of your lymph nodes when they first harvested it. Doctor: Yeah. It had to be there before they did the surgery. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Well that – it was in my lymph nodes, I know that. Family Member: Yeah. They, they harvested a couple, but then they said— Doctor: But if it’s in the lymph node, it’s in the blood stream. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. That was his deal. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: We’re on camera. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Nice to see you. Patient: As long as it’s okay with you. Doctor: Yeah. It’s okay with me as long as it’s okay with you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re just you know, we’re having our usual conversation that we have. What’s new? What’s the deal with going to Alabama and going straight, no breaks? Patient: I took breaks, but I just didn’t take enough. Doctor: Is your leg swollen? Can I take a look? Patient: Yeah. Might have to pull this down. Doctor: Why don’t you come on up here and see what’s going on. Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been.

Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, we can’t, you know. That part’s okay. Let me see this other skinny leg. Patient: Yeah, you’re right they’re skinny. Doctor: There’s no change there so that’s good but you think up here is swollen? Patient: Well, no, I don’t think it’s swollen. It’s just like a… Doctor: A little pain? Patient: Well, the muscle. Doctor: Yeah. Hang on. That’s not swollen. Okay, we got a plan. Patient: Like, huh. Doctor: We got a plan. Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night.

Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

Patient: Well, this only started when I… Doctor: Yeah, so you know… Patient: I’ve been having pain in my back but I had that. That’s when my back was hurting then right after that it was found out that I the cancer and they went ahead so. Doctor: Right, yeah, so we’ll just follow to make sure it’s nothing new, anything new that pops up and of course you’re getting the CAT scan because I want to make sure there’s nothing new in the liver or the lungs or anything as well. I’m not expecting it to but we have to check. Now, if your PSA is just, you know, creeping up, which it kind of is, I know. Patient: It went up. Doctor: Yeah, it did, it did. You’re actually at, wait, you were…. Patient: I was at 19. Doctor: You were 19 and you’re like at 42 I think Patient: Wow. Doctor: so that’s a hint that uh-oh something’s happening. So, we’ve got 2 options because I’m going to assume that your scans might show something is, maybe 1 or 2 new spots or something. Not drastically worse because you don’t look it. You don’t, that’s not how you are. Certainly, you’re better than the first time I met you. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, you’re in better shape, better control, but we have to get early, you know, we have to get an early jump on this. Let’s say the cancer is back or it’s worse. Well, you had that run of chemo so we’re not going to repeat that but other options would be, we actually have 3 studies to consider Patient: mm hmm.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system.

Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: the IV it’s about an hour. How’s that for fancy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s FDA approved for a cool, hundred thousand dollars so your insurance has to say yes number one, now don’t look at me with those eyes of yours. Secondly, we help you through that so that’s on us and if it’s not approved you won’t get it because people can’t, there’s no way we can afford that so we just would leave that but I might just start there to see if we can get the insurance to cover it. Most insurances will cover it, most insurances. So, that’s one. Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Now, the study that goes with that it isn’t whether you get the medicine or not, that’s a done deal, our study is to know what happens to your immune system so every time we see you we take ah blood from you so that we measure. Okay, what is this guy who’s supposed to fight this kind of infection. What’s his level? And what about this gal’s cell? What was she supposed to do? You know, it’s like who’s sleeping on the job Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. It’s kind of a lot but the good news is there’s a lot of options and that’s me banking on everything as the worse-case scenario as, you know, you know, Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: that’s how I am because I don’t want you to fret that there’s nothing to do after we get the scans. We have tons of stuff to do. It’s just being thoughtful about what you want in terms of what’s the best thing. Questions? Patient: Not on that. I had one other.

Patient: Not on that. I had one other. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I was just, is it part of the prostate that your bladder don’t empty all the way sometimes? Doctor: Sometimes. Is that acting up? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m worried about and we’ll certainly capture that when we do the scan. Um, are you just peeing like every hour or what’s going on? Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours. Doctor: hm mmm, yep, yeah, Do you feel like you empty when you pee Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or do you feel there’s a little more in there? Patient: There’s more because you go ahead and pee the full stream then you stop then you, it’s bogged down. Doctor: Yep, Yep, So, do me a favor. Like after seven p.m. at night don’t drink fluid; Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: What did you give him because I have him coming back for the spinal? Doctor: He’ll come back after he gets scanned which will probably be like in a week or two. Healthcare Professional: Okay, so then we will, because he’s due to come back on the 18th and he’ll have research labs then, so that will be a different one. Doctor: I think so. We’ll try to make sure that we have a plan. Healthcare Professional: Okay Doctor: He can’t get rid of us now. Sit tight.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Healthcare Professional: You need to have another (talking over each other) Doctor: Yeah and you need to have it as G____ just pointed out, you need to have an undetectable PSA. Healthcare Professional: Which he has. Doctor: Which you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know on face value suggests that there’s no additional… Patient: No PSA is not the best marker. Doctor: Exactly. Well it is a great marker but sometimes if the cancer cells that are there are in microscopic clusters… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …and they’re not organized enough… Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: …to produce… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …or get their machinery organizes, organized or orchestrated, there’s music… Doctor: …enough to produce enough PSA that we can detect in our blood tests… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …then you know it may take a little while for that to show up. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So you want, you want to, want me - want to know if I want to become involved in a particular? Doctor: I think you would be an excellent candidate for this study because that is obviously the question of the day… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …is whether or not we go for radiation therapy currently or whether or not we just kind of hold tight and check your PSA.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct. Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. Doctor: - for you know unintended injury to things in that area like the bladder, the urethra, ah the colon which - or the rectum which sits right behind. Patient: Sure. Doctor: You can have things like blood in the urine. You can have problems with healing in that area. That’s why we don’t automatically refer people immediately…

Patient: Sure. Doctor: …after surgery because we want the healing process to be well established before we throw in kind of a wild card like radiation that Patient: Mmm. Doctor: might have some impact on healing. So we want you continent of urine, we want you you know having good control of your urine before we… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …we would refer. Healthcare Professional: Right he’s doing really well in that regard. Doctor: Good. Okay. Patient: Not bad. (Laughs) Doctor: Good, good. Patient: I’m going more often than I used to, but I mean that’s old age and what we’ve done I’m sure. Doctor: Yes, exactly.

Healthcare Professional: No. What they’re trying to do is figure out whether it does work better than… Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Than that or the um Xtandi plus the other pill. So that’s what the study is. Xtandi is already approved for… Doctor: I want to be part of this discussion too. Doctor: Of course I am. I’m the one directing it. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: I’m alright. How are you Mr. H___? Nice to see you. How are you? Family Member: Good to see you again. Doctor: Yes, definitely. No you’re good. Healthcare Professional: I was just explaining… Family Member: There’s a chair over there. Healthcare Professional: I’m sorry?

Healthcare Professional: So fatigue is a big one. Patient: I have plenty of fatigue. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: You’ll be tired. Doctor: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that but some things we have to monitor. We always say anything with pills can affect your, your, you know your stomach and your bowels. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Doc -so that’s possible. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum.

Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down.

Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling – Patient: Um. Doctor: - so that your experience gets you know out there Family Member: Right now as I say… Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: He to me… Doctor: Um hmm.

Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s not a great utility for us at this moment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But sometimes if we find that it’s useful later we certainly can. Yeah. Family Member: Now do you think after three months, after he’s on medication, what scans will you be taking? Will you be taking like the - Doctor: The CAT scan.

Patient: We have my father-in-law, Dr. ____ on the phone. Doctor: Okay, hi R____. Family Member: Hi, good morning. Doctor: Yeah, so uh, uh, I think you met them all before. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: and so welcome back, unfortunately. (chuckles) Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones.

Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial. Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive. Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective.

Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we do it in this order for everybody. Patient: Okay. Is the castration, the two years, I understand that is standard care. Are there ever any times when that is shortened or – I understand in my case that is likely two years – I accept that that’s what it’s going to be. Doctor: Okay, okay. Family Member: Is that even in case number three, though, the aggressive with the chemo and the super hormone, or is the hormone; I just want to ask In standard care two you said the hormone shot would be for two years. In the third option with the chemo, how long is that going to be last? Doctor: So the way we’re doing it, it’s still two years.

Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting. Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month.

Patient: Okay, so you’ll know whether the castration is working or not with the hormone Family Member: After the three months of the chemo and hormone pills, how does the hormone deprivation continue? Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___ Doctor: So you can actually go to G____. Patient: Okay, perfect. Family Member: Oh wow! Doctor: I’m sure G____has a machine. Family Member: And they do as good a job to here? Doctor: Oh yeah, same people, same machines.

Family Member: Okay. Patient: Follow-up question here to Doctor: You could do either way. Family Member: Yeah. And how long are you there when you go get your radiation? Doctor: About a half an hour total. So you do it on your way to work or on the way home. Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes? Doctor: Just let us know. Patient: Okay. It won’t take long; I just want to absorb everything. Then I get back. Okay. Doctor: Um, R___ do you have any other questions? Family Member 1: Just the sequence of things. The hormone therapy and the chemo therapy and Zytiga. Are they all started at the same time? Doctor: Uh, pretty much, yeah. Um and we could start the hormone shot any time. Patient: I’m scheduled.

Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Family Member 1: Yeah, I don’t have any additional questions. Doctor: Great. Patient: There you go. Thank you. Family Member: I have a very basic question. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: What does cure mean?

Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called Doctor: Hmmmm Patient: Should I hold off on that during the period of treatment as well? Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All that sugar stuff, all the rocket fuel—it’s all myth. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Right, it’s all myth. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know you can eat red meat once a week. You can drink you know in moderation. Do not ruin - you know it’s all myth, right. People feel very strongly about those myths. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Oh, oh, he can? Doctor: Yeah. It’s only those four days. Family Member: OOH! It’s the first of the week of the week that you get it. But, the the reason that I’d like to talk about it is because it’s possible that we might need to make a switch in your treatment today anyway. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So um it is likely or or possible that I might be giving you a new prescription today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For a different medication anyway.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um, we’ll have to see um what the PSA test looks like today. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But in the last few months it has been going up. Patient: I know it’s high today. Doctor: How do you know that? Patient: I- because I been taking that medicine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And then then I be feelin’- I be for the last Doctor: Okay. Patient: Sometime that would go away. Sometime it stay with me the whole day so. I I wadn’t worryin’ that I’m sayin’ I’m wonderin’ i-i-s it possible its cancer or medicine so. Patient: Yesterday for some reason all in my back was pain from my shoulder blades, to my shoulders all through my back. And I took a uh Nap-nabarone. Doctor: N-naprosyn. Patient: Yeah I took and sleep Doctor: Okay. And did you take one today as well? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So it didn’t come back today? Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you?

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Be to go to a intravenous chemotherapy. Okay. I don’t think I’m going to recommend that for you right now because your symptoms seem to be relatively mild. I’m not fully convinced to whether the pain that you had yesterday was attracted to cancer or could’ve been through something . I’ll try this route Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The chemotherapy has a name. It’s called Docetaxel and it has a second name and that is Taxotere. And this is given through the vein, intravenous, also called I.V. Intravenous I.V. It’s given once every few weeks. And I’m writing this down as an option just so you know what we talked about. But at this point in time, um I think that your cancer is progressing relatively slowly, if at all. Probably at slowly. And I don’t see any immediate need right now to recommend the chemotherapy. But it is an option, we’ll save that for later. I wanna focus our conversation now on the fresh option, which is the Xtandi. So in general in patients who have previously received Abiraterone, that could’ve been you, you would’ve been taking it but you were unable to get access to it for the last two months. Patient: Right. Doctor: If if that is no longer affected then the second drug, Xtandi, uh typically works for about six, sometimes nine months. So it, it doesn’t work for years and years but it does give us a little bit more time before we have to recommend the chemotherapy.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: One of the things we have been interested in is how do we make this drug work better and longer. Okay. And one way to make this drug better, work better and longer is to try to combine it with a second drug that’s experimental. Okay. So the Xtandi itself is not experimental, this has been approved by the FDA more than five years ago. It’s standard, does not require you to participate in a clinical trial and I could just write you a prescription for this medication. The experimental clinical trial that we’re doing which is research, so you would have to sign a permission slip which we call a consent form. Not today but after we’ve had time to look at it. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um and I’ll just flip the page to the back. Okay. It’s a randomized trial. What does randomized mean? Randomized means that at the beginning of the study we flip a coin. Might sound crazy. Doctor: So, I’m going to write randomized. And that coin flip is random. In other words, neither the doctor nor the patient can influence it. We can’t rig the system. Once the coin has been flipped, we can’t flip it again. We can’t keep flipping it until we get the one that we want. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense.
