Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense? Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.”

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? Uh, the other thing to say about Zytiga, is it’s going to be generic soon, but I’m not sure it, if we’re quite there yet. I’m not sure. I can find that out. But, uh, so if you tell me, geez, I really don’t want to take prednisone, then I would do the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Otherwise, I would do the Zytiga. Patient: Yeah. I don’t really want to take prednisone. I saw how it affected her. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams. Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but.

Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens)

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh, so what I could do is talk to the pharmacist about the Xtandi and just figure out what it’s going to cost us, and look into the trials to see, uh, if we would- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I don’t know. Are you interested in doing another trial? Or are you sort of, you did a trial, and you’re ready to-? Patient: Well, no. I mean, anything that, that might help me to survive. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I know. I know. Patient: I’m, I’m interested in. Doctor: Let me, uh- Patient: And plus it also, it, its information that could be useful to maybe help other people. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Let me find out about the, the biopsy requirements today, uh. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I know we have some trials that if you have bone, they do not, you can’t be on the trial, because they just don’t get the tissue.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. Patient: So what, what’s the difference this time? Doctor: Well, I think we saw, you know, a few, you know, small number of spots. We thought like we could radiate them. Maybe those are the only spots. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process?

Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And in, in having an immune drug on board seems to make that whole thing work better. Um, I don’t have the answer for this vaccine radium combination, whether it’s going to do anything. But that’s, that’s the idea behind it is let’s bring these two things together. Uh, so, uh, again, if I had to say which one has the best chance of working for you right now is probably going to be a second hormone treatment. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and I think given where you are with the disease in the bone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I, I would probably lean towards something that I’d feel like we have a better chance of, of success. Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know?

Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico-

Patient: Right. I know. Yeah. That is. That is. Doctor: Unless it’s for a healer. You know? Patient: Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: That is no good. Patient: Yeah. Remember when I was telling you about that, uh, um, HIV drug that they were doing some sort of testing on that was very good for, what was that, brain tumors? (Sound Door closes) Doctor: Yeah. So, I think they’re calling this the same thing. Vitamin B-seventeen is the laetrile? Patient: Yes. It is. It’s the same thing. Doctor: Yes. So I would say, uh, I think that’s not going to work. That would be my- Patient: Yeah. They don’t, they don’t, they don’t- Doctor: From what I know. From what I know about it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so this is what the compound is. It’s called, amygdalin. And this is, it has cyanide. There it is, cyanide.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they-

Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday. Patient: Uh-Uh. Okay. All right. Sounds good. Doctor: I’ll let them know we’re done so they can- Patient: All right. Doctor: I don’t know where the other camera is. Patient: There’s one there, and one there. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: If you, if you go with (game one) Doctor: Okay. Well, I’m guessing you had a- Patient: We had, we had to get up at five-thirty in the morning to go on the safari because that’s when the animals are most active. Yeah. So that was- Doctor: So what did you see? Like what animals did you see? Patient: Oh, we saw, we saw the five big ones. Doctor: Oh, really? Patient: Yeah. The elephant, giraffe, lions. Doctor: And where did you go? What like park or what was? Family Member: Kruger National Park. Patient: Kruger. Doctor: Kruger. Yeah. I’ve heard about that. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Um hum. We was in Cape Town, Johannesburg, these little towns. Patient: Swaziland. Family Member: Swaziland. Patient: Zululand. Hazyview. Family Member: There, we had to cross the border. And so we had to go and show your passport, get stamped, or whatever, and go back across the border. Doctor: To Swaziland? Is that a-? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s like one of those little countries that’s inside of some? Patient: Um hum. Yeah.

We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. So it was- Doctor: Wow. That’s quite- you did way more than just a safari. That’s a lot. Family Member: Oh, yeah. Patient: Oh, way, way. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-?

Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, yeah. That was a deep, deep, deep, deep experience. Doctor: Well, I’m glad it all went well for you. Family Member: Yeah. It was nice. Patient: Yeah.
